entry.title: SVG Gobbler
entry.summary: Great little project from Ross Moody: SVG Gobbler is a browser extension that finds the vector content on the page you‚Äôre viewing and gives you the option to download, optimize, copy, view the code, or export it as an image. ‚Ä¶ The post SVG Gobbler appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Efficient Infinite Utility Helpers Using Inline CSS Custom Properties and calc()
entry.summary: I recently wrote a very basic Sass loop that outputs several padding and margin utility classes. Nothing fancy, really, just a Sass map with 11 spacing values, looped over to create classes for both padding and margin on each side. ‚Ä¶ The post Efficient Infinite Utility Helpers Using Inline CSS Custom Properties and calc() appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Three Buggy React Code Examples and How to Fix Them
entry.summary: There‚Äôs usually more than one way to code a thing in React. And while it‚Äôs possible to create the same thing different ways, there may be one or two approaches that technically work ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than others. entry.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Disabled Buttons
entry.summary: How can we make disabled buttons more inclusive? When do they work well, and when do they fail on us? And finally, when do we actually need them, and how can we avoid them? Let‚Äôs find out.

entry.title: Using CSS Shapes for Interesting User Controls and Navigation
entry.summary: Straight across or down, that‚Äôs the proverbial order for user controls on a screen. Like a list of menu items. But what if we change that to a more fluid layout with bends, curves, and nooks? We can pull it ‚Ä¶ The post Using CSS Shapes for Interesting User Controls and Navigation appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: React Children And Iteration Methods
entry.summary: In this article, we‚Äôll discuss and learn about the use case of iterating over React `children` and the ways to do it. In particular, we will deep dive into one of the utility methods, `React.Children.toArray`, that React gives us, which helps to iterate over the children in a way which ensures performance and determinism.

entry.title: Serverless Functions as Proxies
entry.summary: The first time cloud functions / serverless functions clicked for me was when I saw and tried Auth0‚Äôs (now defunct) Webtask. It was a little CodePen-like IDE but you didn‚Äôt really see anything aside from code and logs. The ‚Ä¶ The post Serverless Functions as Proxies appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Automatic Daily GitHub Backups, Restored in Seconds
entry.summary: Any company that uses GitHub for critical applications needs a backup that can be restored quickly when needed. Cyberattacks, human errors, or a forced push are just some of the scenarios that can result in the loss of GitHub data. ‚Ä¶ The post Automatic Daily GitHub Backups, Restored in Seconds appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: A Deep Dive on Skipping to Content
entry.summary: While most people browsing the web on a computer use a mouse, many rely on their keyboard instead. Theoretically, using a web page with the keyboard should not be a problem ‚Äî press the TAB key to move the keyboard ‚Ä¶ The post A Deep Dive on Skipping to Content appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How To Build Resilient JavaScript UIs
entry.summary: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.

entry.title: CSS Modules (The Native Ones)
entry.summary: They are actually called ‚ÄúCSS Module Scripts‚Äù and are a native browser feature, as opposed to the popular open-source project that essentially does scoped styles by creating unique class name identifiers in both HTML and CSS. Native CSS Modules are ‚Ä¶ The post CSS Modules (The Native Ones) appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How to Code a Playable Synth Keyboard
entry.summary: With a little knowledge of music theory, we can use regular HTML, CSS and JavaScript‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwithout any libraries or audio samples‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâto create a simple digital instrument. Let‚Äôs put that into practice and explore one method for creating ‚Ä¶ The post How to Code a Playable Synth Keyboard appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Refactoring CSS: Strategy, Regression Testing And Maintenance (Part 2)
entry.summary: In this article, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the refactoring process itself, and cover incremental refactoring strategy, visual regression testing, and maintaining the refactored codebase.

entry.summary: Looks like it was almost 9 years ago when Airbnb first published their JavaScript Style Guide. 112k stars on GitHub later, it seems like the de facto preset for Babel / ES Lint. But it‚Äôs not the only company ‚Ä¶ The post A Shared ESLint Configuration appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Conjuring Generative Blobs With The CSS Paint API
entry.summary: The CSS Paint API (part of the magical Houdini family) opens the door to an exciting new world of design in CSS. Using the Paint API, we can create custom shapes, intricate patterns, and beautiful animations ‚Äî all with a ‚Ä¶ The post Conjuring Generative Blobs With The CSS Paint API appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How To Build An E-Commerce Site With Angular 11, Commerce Layer And Paypal
entry.summary: Having an e-commerce store is crucial for any store owner as more and more customers are turning to online shopping. In this tutorial, we shall go through how to create an e-commerce site with Angular 11. The site will use the Commerce Layer as a headless e-commerce API and use Paypal to process payments.

entry.summary: I‚Äôd wager to say that most websites that are business-minded have accounts. A way to log into them. entry.title: Safari 15 Opinions
entry.summary: It was interesting that when Safari 15 was dropping at this last WWDC, in my circles at least, I mostly heard enthusiasm. Like the colors-in-the-browser-controls stuff was a neat trick and fun to play with. And there were other ‚Ä¶ The post Safari 15 Opinions appeared first on CSS-Tricks. entry.title: Creating An Accessible Dialog From Scratch
entry.summary: Dialogs are everywhere in modern interface design (for good or for bad), and yet many of them are not accessible to assistive technologies. In this article, we will dig into how to create a short script to create accessible dialogs.

entry.title: Global vs. Local Styling In Next.js
entry.summary: Next.js has strong opinions about how to organize JavaScript but not CSS. How can we develop patterns that encourage best CSS practices while also following the framework‚Äôs logic? The answer is surprisingly simple ‚Äî to write well-structured CSS that balances global and local styling concerns.

entry.title: How I Built a Cross-Platform Desktop Application with Svelte, Redis, and Rust
entry.summary: At Cloudflare, we have a great product called Workers KV which is a key-value storage layer that replicates globally. It can handle millions of keys, each of which is accessible from within a Worker script at exceptionally low latencies, ‚Ä¶ The post How I Built a Cross-Platform Desktop Application with Svelte, Redis, and Rust appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Gatsby Serverless Functions And The International Space Station
entry.summary: Gatsby recently announced the launch of ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù. In this article, Paul Scanlon explains how to get the current location of the International Space Station (ISS) as it orbits the Earth in real-time using [Gatsby Functions](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/reference/functions/) and then display it on a 3D interactive globe using [React Three Fibre](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber).

entry.title: Web Features That May Not Work As You‚Äôd Expect
entry.summary: As the web gets more and more capable, developers are able to make richer online experiences. There are times, however, where some new web capabilities may not work as you would expect in the interest of usability, security and privacy.‚Ä¶ The post Web Features That May Not Work As You‚Äôd Expect appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: A Guide To Attracting Clients To Your Agency
entry.summary: Many web design agencies consider it a badge of honor that they win work exclusively through word-of-mouth recommendations. In this article, Paul Boag explains why that is entirely the wrong attitude and what to do about it.

entry.title: Organize your CSS declarations alphabetically
entry.summary: Eric, again not mincin‚Äô no words with blog post titles. This is me: The most common CSS declaration organization technique I come across is none whatsoever. Almost none, anyway. I tend to group them by whatever dumps out of my ‚Ä¶ The post Organize your CSS declarations alphabetically appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Using Google Drive as a CMS
entry.summary: We‚Äôre going to walk through the technical process of hooking into Google Drive‚Äôs API to source content on a website. We‚Äôll examine the step-by-step implementation, as well as how to utilize server-side caching to avoid the major pitfalls to avoid ‚Ä¶ The post Using Google Drive as a CMS appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Hashnode: A Blogging Platform for Developers
entry.summary: Hashnode is a free platform for developer blogging. Say you‚Äôve just finished an ambitious project and want to write about 10 important lessons you‚Äôve learned as a developer during it. You should definitely blog it‚ÄîI love that kind of blog post, myself. Making a jump into the technical debt of operating your own blog isn‚Äôt a small choice, but it‚Äôs important to own your own content. With Hashnode, the decision gets a lot easier. You can blog under a site you entirely own, and at the same time, reap the benefits of hosted software tailor-made for developer blogging and be part of a social center around developer writing. The post Hashnode: A Blogging Platform for Developers appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Adding Time To Your Schedule As A Professional
entry.summary: Are you running a business and have too many things going on at once? Meetings, bugs, customer feedback, new clients in addition to your already tight deadlines? Let‚Äôs face it, time management is hard, and it becomes even more difficult in the trying times we are in.

entry.title: Yet Another Mobile Context Menu With No Indication it Can Scroll
entry.summary: Remember Tyler Hall‚Äôs personal story of a UX moment where the popup sharing context menu on iOS had no visible indication that the content inside was scrollable? The thing his mom wanted to do seemed impossible iOS isn‚Äôt alone here ‚Ä¶ The post Yet Another Mobile Context Menu With No Indication it Can Scroll appeared first on CSS-Tricks. entry.title: ECMAScript proposal: JSON modules
entry.summary: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer looks at JSON modules, which is already live in Chrome 91 (but nothing else). It looks just like an ES Modules-style import, only you asset the type at the end. import configData from './config-data.json' assert {type: ‚Ä¶ The post ECMAScript proposal: JSON modules appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: A Step-By-Step Process for Turning Designs Into Code
entry.summary: Turning website design files into a combination of HTML, CSS and JavaScript is the bread and butter of many front-end web development jobs, but there‚Äôs a part of this work that doesn‚Äôt neatly fit in to tutorials on any specific ‚Ä¶ The post A Step-By-Step Process for Turning Designs Into Code appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Color Tools And Resources
entry.summary: Do you need a little inspiration boost? We‚Äôve collected some useful color tools and resources that we‚Äôve discovered lately ‚Äî to help you get the most out of your creativity. We‚Äôve also just recently covered [CSS auditing tools](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-auditing-tools/), [CSS generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/), [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) and [VS code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/) ‚Äî you might find them useful, too.

entry.title: How To Migrate From WordPress To A Headless CMS
entry.summary: In this article, we will look at when it makes sense to migrate from a monolithic project to a headless setup and the benefits that come with it. In addition to a step-by-step guide on how to migrate WordPress to Storyblok Headless CMS, the problems that will arise during the process and how to deal with them.

entry.title: Practical Use Cases for Scroll-Linked Animations in CSS with Scroll Timelines
entry.summary: The Scroll-Linked Animations specification is an upcoming and experimental addition to CSS. Using the @scroll-timeline at-rule and animation-timeline property this specification provides you can control the time position of regular CSS Animations by scrolling. entry.title: Maintaining End-To-End Quality With Visual Testing
entry.summary: By adding visual elements to your tests, you can gain more options to add meaningful ways in maintaining a high level of quality for your app. Colby Fayock explains how.

entry.title: WordPress Admin Warnings in the Block Editor
entry.summary: We sent out an email the other week that ultimately had a <video> in the HTML markup. We send the newsletter by creating it here in the WordPress block editor, which is fetched through RSS-to-Mailchimp. Mailchimp dutifully sent it out, ‚Ä¶ The post WordPress Admin Warnings in the Block Editor appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How to Get a Pixel-Perfect, Linearly Scaled UI
entry.summary: Dynamically scaling CSS values based on the viewport width is hardly a new topic. You can find plenty of in-depth coverage right here on CSS-Tricks in articles like this one or this one. Most of those examples, though, use ‚Ä¶ The post How to Get a Pixel-Perfect, Linearly Scaled UI appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: ISR vs DPR: Big Words, Quick Explanation
entry.summary: There are two strategies for incrementally building websites that are growing in popularity: Incremental Static Regeneration and Distributed Persistent Rendering. What‚Äôs the difference? Let‚Äôs figure it out.

entry.title: You Can Do That With A JavaScript Data Grid?
entry.summary: In this article, you‚Äôll get to see some pretty groundbreaking things you can achieve with modern JavaScript grids and discover new ways to augment a data grid to make it engaging, responsive, and accessible. All this will be illustrated using Kendo UI Data Grids and their features.

entry.title: Build Complex CSS Transitions using Custom Properties and cubic-bezier()
entry.summary: I recently illustrated how we can achieve complex CSS animations using cubic-bezier() and how to do the same when it comes to CSS transitions. I was able to create complex hover effect without resorting to keyframes. In this article, I ‚Ä¶ The post Build Complex CSS Transitions using Custom Properties and cubic-bezier() appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: A Bashful Button Worth $8 Million
entry.summary: Most of us grumble when running across a frustrating UX experience online (like not being able to complete a transaction because of a misplaced button). We might pen a whiny tweet. Jason Grigsby is like I‚Äôm going to write 2,000 ‚Ä¶ The post A Bashful Button Worth $8 Million appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Broken Filters
entry.summary: Too often dealing with filters can be frustrating. Let‚Äôs get them right. That means never freeze the UI on a single input, provide text input fallback and never auto-scroll users on a single input. Here‚Äôs why.

entry.summary: As a day-job, React-using person, I like to stay abreast of interesting React news. As such, I save a healthy amount of links. Allow me to dump out my latest pile. Most of this is about React but not all ‚Ä¶ The post Links on React and JavaScript appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Meta Theme Color and Trickery
entry.summary: Starting with Version 15, Safari supports the theme-color <meta> tag both on macOS and iOS. That‚Äôs exciting news because now the first desktop browser supports this <meta> tag and it also supports the media attribute and the prefers-color-scheme media feature.‚Ä¶ The post Meta Theme Color and Trickery appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Jamstack Community Survey 2021
entry.summary: (This is a sponsored post.) The folks over at Netlify have opened up the Jamstack Community Survey for 2021. More than 3,000 front-enders like yourself took last year‚Äôs survey, which gauged how familiar people are with the ‚Ä¶ The post Jamstack Community Survey 2021 appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Building A Dynamic Header With Intersection Observer
entry.summary: In JavaScript, attaching an event listener to constantly fire a callback on scroll can be performance-intensive. But there is a better way with Intersection Observer.

entry.title: How To Migrate From jQuery To Next.js
entry.summary: In this article, we‚Äôre taking a closer look at different approaches and strategies on how we can migrate a web application that uses jQuery framework, and start using one of the coolest React frameworks in the market: Next.js.

entry.title: Meet `:has`, A Native CSS Parent Selector
entry.summary: The reasons that are often cited that make container queries difficult or impossible is things like infinite loops‚Äîe.g. changing the width of an element, invalidating a container query, which changes the width again, which makes the container query take effect, ‚Ä¶ The post Meet `:has`, A Native CSS Parent Selector appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Using the Specificity of :where() as a CSS Reset
Refactoring CSS: Introduction (Part 1)
entry.summary: CSS refactoring is not an easy task ‚Äî it needs to be done in a way that doesn't create problems. First we need to analyze the existing codebase, audit CSS codebase health, discover weaknesses, agree on the approach, and convince management to invest time and resources into the process.
